value_capture_and_asymmetry.partner_or_channel: Hyperscalers (AWS, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud Platform)
value_capture_and_asymmetry.enterprise_value_contributed: Rackspace contributes: (1) CUSTOMER ACQUISITION - sales and marketing to win customers who might otherwise buy hyperscaler-direct, (2) CUSTOMER MANAGEMENT - 24x7 support, monitoring, architecture guidance reducing hyperscaler support burden, (3) CONSUMPTION GROWTH - managed services that optimize and grow customer cloud usage over time, increasing hyperscaler infrastructure revenue, (4) MARKET EXPANSION - serves customers too small or specialized for hyperscaler direct sales (mid-market, specific verticals), (5) BILLING SIMPLIFICATION - consolidated billing and account management for multi-cloud customers. Rackspace is CUSTOMER ACQUISITION CHANNEL and SUPPORT OUTSOURCER for hyperscalers.
value_capture_and_asymmetry.partner_value_contributed: Hyperscalers contribute: (1) INFRASTRUCTURE - 100% of actual cloud services (compute, storage, database, AI/ML, etc.) that customers consume, (2) PRODUCT INNOVATION - continuous platform improvements and new services that Rackspace cannot replicate, (3) BRAND POWER - customers explicitly buying 'AWS' or 'Azure' services, not Rackspace proprietary platform, (4) PRICING CONTROL - hyperscalers set list rates that Rackspace bills customers (price-setting power), (5) PARTNER ECONOMICS - hyperscaler-provided credits/rebates (5-15%) that constitute Rackspace's infrastructure margin, (6) CUSTOMER VISIBILITY - hyperscalers can see customer workloads and consumption patterns, enabling direct sales solicitation. Hyperscalers provide 100% of product value, Rackspace provides service wrapper.
value_capture_and_asymmetry.value_capture_split: DEEPLY ASYMMETRIC favoring hyperscalers: Of total customer spend, hyperscalers capture 89.6% (infrastructure at list rates), Rackspace captures 10.4% (management services + partner credits). However, RACKSPACE BEARS MAJORITY OF COSTS: Rackspace pays for sales/marketing to acquire customer, delivery personnel to manage infrastructure, support operations, account management. Hyperscalers receive 89.6% of revenue with MINIMAL incremental cost (marginal cost of additional compute/storage consumption is <10% per hyperscaler economics). Net: Hyperscalers earn estimated 60-70% operating margin on Rackspace-sourced revenue, Rackspace earns estimated 15-25% operating margin on Public Cloud segment (Stage 2.4 estimate). VALUE CAPTURE PER DOLLAR OF CUSTOMER SPEND: Hyperscaler profit $0.55-0.65, Rackspace profit $0.02-0.03 (20-30X asymmetry).
value_capture_and_asymmetry.who_benefits_more_and_why: HYPERSCALERS BENEFIT FAR MORE: (1) ECONOMICS: Hyperscalers capture 89.6% of revenue with minimal incremental cost, Rackspace captures 10.4% while bearing majority of customer acquisition and service delivery costs. (2) STRATEGIC CONTROL: Hyperscalers control pricing (can reduce prices, compressing Rackspace margin), product roadmap (Rackspace dependent on hyperscaler innovation), and partner programs (can reduce/eliminate partner credits). (3) CUSTOMER RELATIONSHIP: Customers know they're buying AWS/Azure/Google - hyperscaler brand, not Rackspace brand. Hyperscalers can directly solicit customers to go direct. (4) OPTIONALITY: Hyperscalers have thousands of customers and partners - losing Rackspace is immaterial (<1% of AWS/Azure/Google revenue). Rackspace has 61% of revenue dependent on hyperscaler partnerships - losing partnerships would eliminate majority of business. (5) DISINTERMEDIATION PATH: Hyperscalers increasingly offer native managed services (AWS Managed Services, Azure Managed Services) competing directly with Rackspace, enabling customer migration to hyperscaler-direct and eliminating Rackspace margin entirely. DEPENDENCE: Rackspace is EXISTENTIALLY DEPENDENT on hyperscalers (cannot deliver Public Cloud without them), hyperscalers are NOT DEPENDENT on Rackspace (one of thousands of reseller partners, easily replaceable).
evidence_sources: Stage 2.2: Public Cloud gross margin 10.4%, implying hyperscalers capture 89.6% of customer spend
Stage 2.2: 'Rackspace bills AWS infrastructure at list rates (pass-through), capturing partner credits/rebates (estimated 5-15%) as infrastructure margin'
Stage 2.4: Mid-Market Public Cloud estimated 15-25% operating margin (after allocating overhead)
Stage 2.1: Public Cloud $1,683M (61% of total revenue) depends on hyperscaler partnerships
Stage 2.2: 'Hyperscalers can modify partner programs, reducing Rackspace's infrastructure margin' - demonstrates control asymmetry
Stage 2.2: 'Hyperscalers offering native managed services... can undercut Rackspace by eliminating reseller layer'
Industry knowledge: AWS/Azure/Google operating margins 25-35% on public cloud services, while reseller partners earn single-digit margins
Calculated asymmetry: If customer pays $100, hyperscalers get $89.60 profit ~$55-65, Rackspace gets $10.40 profit ~$2-3

value_capture_and_asymmetry.enterprise_value_contributed: Rackspace contributes: (1) CUSTOMER BASE - Private Cloud customers using VMware platform managed by Rackspace, (2) INFRASTRUCTURE DEPLOYMENT - purchases VMware licenses and deploys VMware infrastructure in Rackspace data centers, (3) OPERATIONAL MANAGEMENT - staffs VMware specialists to manage customer environments (reducing customer need for in-house VMware expertise), (4) CUSTOMER RETENTION - manages customer relationships and renewals, preventing customer migration to alternative platforms, (5) LICENSE VOLUME - Rackspace's Private Cloud business generates meaningful VMware license revenue (estimated $20-50M+ annually based on $1,055M Private Cloud revenue requiring VMware licensing). Rackspace is CAPTIVE CUSTOMER and DISTRIBUTION CHANNEL for VMware.
value_capture_and_asymmetry.partner_value_contributed: VMware contributes: (1) VIRTUALIZATION PLATFORM - vSphere, vSAN, NSX software that enables Private Cloud infrastructure, (2) CUSTOMER LOCK-IN - VMware-specific configurations create migration friction keeping customers on Rackspace Private Cloud (cannot easily switch to non-VMware providers), (3) ENTERPRISE CREDIBILITY - VMware brand provides enterprise customer confidence in Private Cloud offering, (4) OPERATIONAL CONTINUITY - ongoing support and updates required to maintain production infrastructure. However, VMware is SUBSTITUTABLE in theory (OpenStack, Microsoft Hyper-V alternatives exist) but LOCKED-IN in practice (migration risk and cost prohibitive).
value_capture_and_asymmetry.value_capture_split: ASYMMETRIC favoring VMware POST-BROADCOM ACQUISITION: Historical split (pre-Broadcom): VMware licensing estimated 5-10% of Private Cloud revenue ($50-105M of $1,055M), Rackspace captured 38.6% gross margin ($407M gross profit) with VMware as cost input. POST-BROADCOM SPLIT (2024+): VMware raised prices 200-300%, increasing licensing from $50-105M to potentially $150-315M (estimated), compressing Rackspace gross margin from 38.6% to estimated 25-30% if costs absorbed OR triggering customer churn if passed through. VMware captured estimated $100-210M incremental profit from price increase (pure margin expansion on existing customer base), while Rackspace margin compressed or revenue declined. VALUE CAPTURE SHIFT: Broadcom acquisition shifted value from Rackspace to VMware - what was Rackspace profit became VMware licensing cost. BARGAINING POWER: VMware has pricing power (captive customer base), Rackspace has no leverage (migration to alternatives is multi-year, high-risk, likely accelerates customer churn to public cloud).
value_capture_and_asymmetry.who_benefits_more_and_why: VMWARE (BROADCOM) BENEFITS MORE POST-ACQUISITION: (1) PRICE SHOCK CAPTURE: 200-300% price increase captured $100-210M incremental profit from Rackspace and other VMware customers with LIMITED ATTRITION (migration friction creates short-term captivity). (2) LOCK-IN ADVANTAGE: Rackspace cannot migrate customers off VMware without 20-30% migration failure rate and multi-year timeline, forcing Rackspace to absorb price increases or pass through (churn risk either way). (3) STRATEGIC OPTIONALITY: VMware has thousands of enterprise customers - Rackspace is <1% of VMware revenue (estimated). Rackspace has 39% of revenue dependent on Private Cloud using VMware - VMware price shock threatens entire segment viability. (4) NO COMPETITIVE PRESSURE: Alternative virtualization platforms (OpenStack, Hyper-V) lack feature parity and ecosystem maturity, limiting Rackspace's ability to switch. (5) BROADCOM STRATEGY: Broadcom executed classic private equity playbook - acquire platform with captive customer base, raise prices aggressively, accept 20-30% customer attrition while extracting maximum profit from remaining 70-80%. Rackspace is VICTIM of this strategy. DEPENDENCE: Rackspace is CAPTIVE CUSTOMER of VMware (cannot exit without destroying Private Cloud business), VMware is NOT DEPENDENT on Rackspace (one of many enterprise customers, replaceable).
evidence_sources: Stage 2.2: 'Broadcom acquired VMware (Nov 2023) and IMMEDIATELY raised prices 200-300%' - documented market reality
Stage 2.2: 'Rackspace faces: (1) Massive cost increase, (2) Customer backlash if passed through, (3) Margin compression if absorbed internally'
Stage 2.2: 'Cannot migrate existing VMware customers to alternatives without multi-year migrations with 20-30% failure rate'
Stage 2.1: Private Cloud $1,055M revenue declining 13% YoY, gross margin 38.6% under pressure
Calculated impact: 200-300% increase on estimated $50-105M VMware costs = $100-210M cost increase, compressing 38.6% margin to 25-30%
Industry reporting: CRN, The Register documented Broadcom VMware price increases and enterprise customer backlash
Stage 1.3: 'Rackspace bet heavily on VMware for Private Cloud... Broadcom price shock is consequence of platform dependency'

value_capture_and_asymmetry.partner_or_channel: FedRAMP Joint Authorization Board (JAB) and Federal Government Certification Bodies
value_capture_and_asymmetry.enterprise_value_contributed: Rackspace contributes: (1) COMPLIANCE INVESTMENT - $10-20M+ initial investment to obtain FedRAMP JAB authorization (3PAO assessment, remediation, documentation) plus ongoing annual compliance costs $2-5M+ (continuous monitoring, annual assessments), (2) ISOLATED INFRASTRUCTURE - dedicated data centers, networks, and systems separate from commercial operations to meet FedRAMP requirements, (3) US CITIZEN WORKFORCE - hires and maintains 100% US citizen security team in continental US (higher cost, limited talent pool), (4) OPERATIONAL CONSTRAINTS - accepts architectural isolation, personnel restrictions, and operational inefficiencies required for authorization, (5) RE-AUTHORIZATION RISK - bears risk that change of control or compliance failure invalidates authorization, forcing 12-18 month re-authorization with customer loss. Rackspace absorbs ALL COSTS of compliance, FedRAMP provides only permission.
value_capture_and_asymmetry.partner_value_contributed: FedRAMP provides: (1) MARKET ACCESS - federal agencies LEGALLY REQUIRED to use FedRAMP-authorized providers, creating regulatory moat, (2) CUSTOMER CONFIDENCE - FedRAMP authorization signals to federal customers that security/compliance requirements are met, (3) COMPETITIVE FILTER - FedRAMP barrier to entry ($10-20M+ and 12-18 months) limits competition to ~100 authorized providers vs thousands of cloud providers, (4) PRICING SUPPORT - compliance-driven procurement enables pricing premium (customers will pay more for authorized provider). However, FedRAMP provides NO revenue, NO customers, NO technology, NO operational support - only PERMISSION TO COMPETE in federal market. Customers still choose among ~100 FedRAMP alternatives based on price, features, and service quality.
value_capture_and_asymmetry.value_capture_split: RACKSPACE CAPTURES ECONOMIC VALUE, FEDRAMP CAPTURES REGULATORY CONTROL: FedRAMP receives $0 revenue (government authorization body, not commercial entity). Rackspace captures estimated $270-410M Government segment revenue with estimated 25-35% operating margin ($70-145M profit). However, FEDRAMP CONTROLS MARKET ACCESS - can revoke authorization (terminating revenue), impose additional requirements (increasing costs), or modify authorization process (affecting new entrants). VALUE ALLOCATION: Rackspace earns profit from Government customers but ONLY IF authorization maintained. Authorization costs ($2-5M+ annually) are MANDATORY TAX on Government business. Net capture: Rackspace retains ~$65-140M operating profit after compliance costs, but profit is CONDITIONAL on maintaining authorization (fragile).
value_capture_and_asymmetry.who_benefits_more_and_why: ASYMMETRIC BUT DIFFERENT DIMENSIONS: ECONOMICALLY Rackspace benefits (captures $70-145M operating profit from Government segment enabled by FedRAMP). STRATEGICALLY FedRAMP controls (can terminate market access, eliminating 100% of Government revenue with zero compensation). DEPENDENCY: Rackspace is EXISTENTIALLY DEPENDENT on FedRAMP authorization (Government segment revenue goes to zero without authorization), FedRAMP is NOT DEPENDENT on Rackspace (one of ~100 authorized providers, easily replaceable). HOWEVER, THIS IS STANDARD REGULATORY RELATIONSHIP: All 100 FedRAMP providers have same dependency on authorization. Rackspace is not uniquely disadvantaged vs competitors in this relationship. RISK: Authorization dependency creates CHANGE OF CONTROL CONSTRAINT - foreign acquirer cannot maintain FedRAMP without proxy board and loss of economic control (Stage 1.5), domestic acquirer triggers 12-18 month re-authorization with service disruption and customer loss risk. Rackspace captures economic value but FedRAMP authorization creates STRATEGIC CONSTRAINT limiting M&A optionality and exit paths.
evidence_sources: Stage 2.4: Government segment estimated $270-410M revenue (10-15% of total) with estimated 25-35% operating margin
Calculated profit: $270-410M revenue × 25-35% margin = $70-145M operating profit
Stage 1.5: FedRAMP authorization cost $10-20M+ initial, estimated $2-5M+ annual compliance (industry standard from FedRAMP 3PAO data)
Stage 1.5: 'FedRAMP authorization tied to Rackspace Government Solutions entity... Cannot transfer without 12-18 month re-authorization'
Stage 1.5: 'Change of control to foreign acquirer INVALIDATES FedRAMP authorization'
FedRAMP Marketplace: ~100 authorized cloud service providers creates competitive market, not monopoly/oligopoly
Stage 2.4: Government customers 'LEGALLY REQUIRED to use FedRAMP-authorized providers' creates market access dependency

value_capture_and_asymmetry.partner_or_channel: UK Data Sovereignty Certification Bodies and Compliance Framework
value_capture_and_asymmetry.enterprise_value_contributed: Rackspace contributes: (1) COMPLIANCE INVESTMENT - estimated $5-15M initial investment to build architecturally isolated UK Sovereign infrastructure (separate data centers, networks, systems) plus ongoing annual compliance costs $1-3M+ (audits, certifications, monitoring), (2) UK-ISOLATED INFRASTRUCTURE - dedicated UK-only facilities that cannot be shared with global operations or amortized across larger customer base, (3) UK WORKFORCE - hires and maintains UK-resident personnel exclusively for UK Sovereign (eliminating global workforce arbitrage), (4) BT PARTNERSHIP COSTS - potential partnership with British Telecom for infrastructure/connectivity (terms unknown but likely favorable to BT given UK national champion status), (5) ARCHITECTURAL CONSTRAINTS - accepts permanent separation from global operations, eliminating economies of scale and operational synergies, (6) MARKET DEVELOPMENT RISK - launched March 2024, segment is immature with uncertain customer adoption and profitability timeline (likely 2-3 years to breakeven). Rackspace absorbs ALL COSTS of building UK Sovereign capability on speculation of future demand.
value_capture_and_asymmetry.partner_value_contributed: UK compliance framework provides: (1) MARKET ACCESS - UK government, NHS, police, regulated financial services REQUIRE data sovereignty compliance post-Brexit, creating regulatory requirement, (2) COMPETITIVE MOAT - architectural isolation requirement limits competition to UK-only providers (excludes US hyperscalers and global MSPs unless they build separate UK entities), (3) EARLY-MOVER ADVANTAGE - Rackspace launched March 2024, AWS UK Sovereign Cloud announced but not fully operational, limited competition in early market, (4) PRICING SUPPORT - compliance-driven procurement enables estimated 10-20% pricing premium vs standard UK commercial cloud. However, UK compliance provides NO revenue, NO customers, NO technology - only PERMISSION TO COMPETE in UK sovereign market. Market size is UNCERTAIN - UK sovereign cloud may be small niche ($50-200M TAM) or larger growth market ($500M+ TAM).
value_capture_and_asymmetry.value_capture_split: RACKSPACE CAPTURES FUTURE ECONOMIC VALUE (IF SEGMENT SUCCEEDS), COMPLIANCE FRAMEWORK CONTROLS MARKET ACCESS: UK compliance receives $0 revenue (government regulatory framework, not commercial entity). Rackspace captures UK Sovereign revenue (currently <$135M estimated, likely <$50M in first year post-March 2024 launch). Segment is likely UNPROFITABLE currently (investment phase, fixed infrastructure costs not covered by immature revenue base). VALUE PROJECTION: If segment scales to $200-300M revenue over 3-5 years with estimated 30-40% operating margin (compliance premium), Rackspace could capture $60-120M annual profit. However, IF SEGMENT FAILS (insufficient customer demand, AWS UK Sovereign captures market, UK compliance requirements relax), Rackspace's $5-15M+ investment becomes sunk cost with ZERO recovery value (infrastructure cannot be repurposed for non-UK operations per architectural isolation). RISK/REWARD: Rackspace bears 100% of investment risk and development costs, UK compliance provides market access but no guarantee of customer demand or profitability.
value_capture_and_asymmetry.who_benefits_more_and_why: UNCERTAIN - OUTCOME DEPENDENT: IF segment succeeds (scales to $200-300M+ with 30-40% margins), RACKSPACE BENEFITS (captures $60-120M+ annual profit, provides growth narrative in declining business, demonstrates strategic repositioning capability). IF segment fails (insufficient demand, competition, or compliance evolution), RACKSPACE BEARS LOSS ($5-15M+ sunk investment, stranded UK infrastructure, wasted management attention, damaged UK market credibility). UK compliance framework is NEUTRAL REGARDLESS OF OUTCOME - provides market access rules but no economic exposure. DEPENDENCY: Rackspace is DEPENDENT on UK compliance framework (cannot serve UK sovereign market without compliance), UK compliance is NOT DEPENDENT on Rackspace (framework exists regardless of Rackspace participation, other providers available). STRATEGIC CONSTRAINT: Architectural isolation requirement creates PERMANENT SEPARATION - UK Sovereign can NEVER be integrated with global operations, limiting synergies and forcing standalone economics. Even if successful, UK Sovereign contributes to Rackspace only as SEPARATE PORTFOLIO COMPANY, not integrated business line.
evidence_sources: Stage 2.4: UK Sovereign estimated <5% of total revenue (<$135M), launched March 2024, likely immature and unprofitable
Stage 1.V: 'UK Sovereign ARCHITECTURALLY ISOLATED... Infrastructure CANNOT be shared with global Rackspace network'
Stage 1.V: 'Integration with global operations PERMANENTLY PROHIBITED'
Estimated investment: $5-15M for isolated infrastructure build-out (data centers, systems, personnel) based on FedRAMP precedent and smaller UK market
Estimated future profit: IF segment scales to $200-300M with 30-40% margins = $60-120M annual profit (Stage 2.4 margin estimates for compliance segments)
Stage 2.4: 'UK Sovereign customers likely 20-30% annual churn in first 2-3 years... stabilizing to 10-15%' indicates market immaturity risk
Stage 2.1: 'UK Sovereign can only be valued STANDALONE by UK buyer - cannot be integrated with non-UK operations'

value_capture_and_asymmetry.partner_or_channel: Email Hosting Reseller and Partner Channel
value_capture_and_asymmetry.enterprise_value_contributed: Rackspace contributes: (1) EMAIL PLATFORM - infrastructure, operations, spam filtering, security for email hosting service (fixed costs estimated $10-30M annually for platform), (2) WHOLESALE PRICING - provides email service to partners at wholesale rates (historically $1-3/mailbox/month) enabling partner markup and profit margin, (3) WHITE-LABEL CAPABILITY - partners can rebrand email service as their own offering (Rackspace invisible to end customers), (4) PARTNER PORTAL - provisioning tools and systems enabling partners to manage customer accounts, (5) TECHNICAL SUPPORT - second-line support for partner escalations. Rackspace provides entire product infrastructure, partners provide only customer acquisition and first-line support.
value_capture_and_asymmetry.partner_value_contributed: Partners contribute: (1) CUSTOMER ACQUISITION - sales and marketing to SMB customers who would not buy directly from Rackspace, (2) CUSTOMER RELATIONSHIPS - billing, support, and account management (Rackspace has no direct customer contact), (3) CHANNEL BREADTH - partners reach thousands of SMBs through existing customer bases (web hosting, IT services, etc.), (4) PAYMENT COLLECTION - partners handle billing and collections, reducing Rackspace bad debt risk. Partners are CUSTOMER ACQUISITION CHANNEL and RELATIONSHIP LAYER between Rackspace and end customers.
value_capture_and_asymmetry.value_capture_split: HISTORICALLY BALANCED, NOW RACKSPACE EXTRACTING: Historical split (pre-price increase): Partners bought wholesale $1-3/mailbox, sold retail $5-8/mailbox, captured $2-5/mailbox margin. Rackspace captured $1-3/mailbox wholesale revenue covering platform costs (breakeven to low-margin). SPLIT: Partners captured 40-60% of customer spend, Rackspace captured 40-60%, with partners bearing customer acquisition costs and Rackspace bearing platform costs. POST-PRICE-INCREASE SPLIT (March 2026): Rackspace raised wholesale to $6-10/mailbox (706% increase), attempting to capture majority of customer spend. IF partners maintained $5-8/mailbox retail pricing (constrained by Microsoft 365/Google Workspace competition), partners now LOSE MONEY on every mailbox ($6-10 cost > $5-8 price). Partners must either: (A) Raise retail prices to $12-15/mailbox (triggering massive customer churn per Stage 2.1), OR (B) Accept negative margins (unsustainable), OR (C) Migrate customers to alternative email providers (terminate Rackspace relationship). VALUE CAPTURE ATTEMPT: Rackspace trying to extract $5-7/mailbox incremental profit from partners, but DESTROYING CHANNEL RELATIONSHIP and triggering mass customer exodus. NET RESULT: Total value pool collapsing as customers churn to Microsoft/Google - neither Rackspace nor partners capture value.
value_capture_and_asymmetry.who_benefits_more_and_why: NEITHER PARTY BENEFITS - MUTUAL VALUE DESTRUCTION: (1) PARTNERS HARMED: 706% wholesale price increase makes email hosting unprofitable for partners (cannot pass through to customers due to Microsoft/Google competition). Partners face: (A) Immediate customer churn if they raise prices, (B) Negative margins if they absorb increase, (C) Customer migration costs if they switch providers. Partners describing increase as 'devastating' per Stage 2.1. (2) RACKSPACE HARMED: Price increase triggering 'immediate churn' and 'wave of churn' per Stage 2.1, destroying revenue base. If 60-70% of customers churn, total email revenue DECLINES despite price increase (e.g., $100M revenue at $2/mailbox with 50M mailboxes → $50M revenue at $8/mailbox with 6M mailboxes after 88% churn). Email segment likely becomes loss-making as fixed platform costs spread over dramatically smaller mailbox base. (3) CUSTOMERS MIGRATE: Winners are MICROSOFT and GOOGLE who capture churning email customers at $5-6/user/month for full productivity suite (Microsoft 365, Google Workspace). DEATH SPIRAL: Rackspace price increase → customer churn → remaining customers bear higher per-mailbox cost → more churn → eventual platform shutdown or fire-sale to acquirer. ASYMMETRY: Partners can switch email providers (Microsoft/Google eager to win SMB customers), Rackspace CANNOT easily exit email segment (platform shutdown requires customer migrations, damages relationships, brand harm).
evidence_sources: Stage 2.1: Email hosting '706% PRICE INCREASE' effective March 2026, '$1-3/mailbox to $6-10/mailbox'
Stage 2.1: 'Partners report immediate churn', 'devastating impact', 'unsustainable for most SMBs' indicating channel revolt
Stage 2.1: Microsoft 365 Business Basic $6/user/month with full Office suite, Google Workspace similar - competitive pricing pressure
Stage 2.4: Email segment estimated $135-275M revenue (5-10% of total) with estimated 0-10% margin or loss-making
Calculated churn impact: If 60-70% customer loss, revenue declines despite price increase (volume loss exceeds price gain)
Stage 2.4: SMB segment 'ZERO LOCK-IN', 'email migration is TRIVIAL (1-5 days)' - enables rapid customer departure
Stage 2.1: 'Email hosting DEATH SPIRAL' characterization from partner price increase analysis
